Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit.
Higher organisms occasionally form aberrant individuals with their entire genetic blueprint doubled relative to that of their parents. While the vast majority of these individuals quickly go extinct, in exceedingly rare cases such "genome duplications" give rise to new lineages that appear to realize numerous advantages resulting from having "spare" copies of each gene. Across hundreds of millions of years of evolution, these rare "success stories" collectively are one of the most important mechanisms by which new genes and new functions evolve. Flowering plants (angiosperms) are more tolerant of genome duplication than most taxa - virtually all have experienced genome duplication at least once and sometimes 3-4 times in the past 150-200 million years, and many neo-polyploids formed in the past 1-2 million years are known including many major crops. With the sequences of a growing number of angiosperm genomes now available, the investigators have identified a population of genes that are distinctive in having (a) higher-than average rates of loss for one but not both member(s) of duplicate pairs, (b) convergent fates across multiple independent duplication events within and/or among lineages, and (c) a higher-than-random degree of correlated gene expression. Herein, the investigators will begin empirical tests of fitness effects associated with both the general population of these "duplication-resistant" genes and specific members, seeking genetic probes into pathways and functions contributing to adaptation of a genome to the duplicated state.

Broader Impacts.
The experimental facility of Arabidopsis will expedite analysis of some of the most important evolutionary forces shaping eukaryotic genomes, and in particular underlying the biodiversity that enables angiosperms to provide many ecosystem services including most of the worlds food, feed, and fiber. Better understanding of adaptation by a lineage to genome duplication is not only of fundamental interest but may also have practical applications, either directly by improving productivity of polyploid crops, or indirectly by mitigating obstacles to wider use of naturally-occurring germplasm resources in crop improvement. This research is closely tied to the education of students and the public, providing training opportunities at both pre- and postgraduate levels, and contributing to development and implementation of research-based educational materials to improve achievement, comprehension and mastery of scientific concepts by middle and high school students, also building the nucleus for a "teachers teach teachers" program.

This project is co-funded by the Arabidopsis 2010 Project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Genome sequences for about 30 flowering plants have provided rich new insight into the evolution of this important branch of the tree of life, which provides most of our food, feed, and fiber, many medicines, and a growing share of our fuel.  One of the most striking features that differentiates flowering plants (angiosperms) from other organisms is their propensity for genome duplication, the doubling of gene and chromosomal complements due either to ‘errors’ in gamete formation, or ‘illegitimate’ hybridization between species that are normally reproductively isolated.  Genome duplication is of central importance to forming the diversity that has permitted flowering plants to adapt to much of the planet, and to provide us with the ecosystem services above and more.  Comparison of plant genomes sequenced to date has revealed that particular genes have correlated fates following genome duplication in different lineages.  Specifically, some genes are preferentially retained in duplicate, while others are consistently restored to singleton status following many independent duplications. Here, we have begun a transition from computational inferences about gene fates, to empirical testing of functions associated with these different patterns of gene fates during adaptation of genomes to the duplicated state. By improving knowledge of plant genes and approaches for their study, we potentially impact a host of ecosystem services provided by plants, in nature, agriculture, medicine, recreation/sporting events, and other contexts. Many important crops are recently-formed polyploids, and adaptation to the duplicated state may be responsible for much of the diversity available for improvement of these important crops. A better understanding of specific genes important to the process would permit targeted investigation of fates of key genes in natural polyploids. Engineered silencing of those DR genes not already silenced might improve crops. Of much larger potential impact is the long-term possibility that we learn to streamline the production and use of ‘synthetic’ (manmade) polyploids. Genetic resources in many crops are richer at the diploid level than among polyploids. There have been a few successes in utilizing diploid genetic resources in polyploid crops via ‘synthetic’ polyploids but this area has suffered from the difficulty of producing viable and fertile polyploids. Better understanding of adaptation to the duplicated state might, in the long term, lead to genetic strategies to mitigate obstacles to wider use of the worlds germplasm resources.
